column1: There are eight capital cities in Australia
column2: each of which functions as the seat of government for the state or territory in which it is located. One of these
column4: is also the national capital. Section 125 of the Constitution of Australia specified that the seat of the national government
column7: would be in its own territory within New South Wales
column8: at least 100 miles from Sydney. The Constitution specified that until this national capital was ready
column9: the Parliament would sit in Melbourne. In 1927
column10: the national capital was finally ready and the national government relocated from its former seat in Melbourne to Canberra within the Australian Capital Territory (or the Federal Capital Territory as it was known at the time).

column1: In each state and internal territory
column2: the capital is also the jurisdiction's most populous city. The Australian external territory of Norfolk Island has its official capital at Kingston
column3: although this acts merely as the administrative centre of government; its de facto capital is Burnt Pine.
